title-group.article-title: Research progress of TiO2 photocathodic protection to metals in marine environment

institution-wrap.institution: Key Laboratory of Marine Environmental Corrosion and Bio-fouling, Institute of Oceanology
Open Studio for Marine Corrosion and Protection
Pilot National Laboratory for Marine Science and Technology
University of Chinese Academy of Sciences

permissions.copyright-statement: © Chinese Society for Oceanology and Limnology, Science Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020
permissions.copyright-holder: Chinese Society for Oceanology and Limnology, Science Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Corrosion protection has become an important issue as the amount of infrastructure construction in marine environment increased. Photocathodic protection is a promising method to reduce the corrosion of metals, and titanium dioxide (TiO2) is the most widely used photoanode. This review summarizes the progress in TiO2 photogenerated protection in recent years. Different types of semiconductors, including sulfides, metals, metal oxides, polymers, and other materials, are used to design and modify TiO2. The strategy to dramatically improve the efficiency of photoactivity is proposed, and the mechanism is investigated in detail. Characterization methods are also introduced, including morphology testing, light absorption, photoelectrochemistry, and protected metal observation. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of TiO2 development and guide photocathodic protection.

custom-meta.meta-value: Chinese Society for Oceanology and Limnology, Science Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature

notes.p: Supported by the CAS Strategic Priority Project (No. XDA13040404), the National Natural Science Foundation of China for Exploring Key Scientific Instrument (No. 41827805), and the Shandong Key Laboratory of Corrosion Science

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: Data sharing not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.
